discussion.content: MD5 is the only cryptographic hashing algorithm on this list.
MD5 is a cryptographic hashing function, which by definition means that it is only computed in one direction and it is not possible to "reverse" it back to its original form

The question maybe confusing but if you think about it MD5 is the only hashing algorithm and you can't reverse the MD5 hash to bring back the original form. You can however compare hashes. MD5 is correct.

Hashing is a one way cryptographic function which takes an input and produces a unique message digest(as its output). This is irreversible. MD5, Sha-1, Sha-2 Sha3 are all Hashing Algorithms, 

while rest of them are encryption algorithms

Hashing is not the same thing as encryption and decryption. Hashes cannot be reversed or decrypted; they can only be compared to see if they match (Mike Meyer’s CompTIA Security+ p. 89).
MD5 produces a 128-bit message digest, consisting of 32 hexadecimal characters, regardless of the length of the input text (Mike Meyer’s CompTIA Security+ p. 90).
D is the only hashing algorithm

I thought this was BS too because in my mind, MD5 was off the list due to being a hash function buuuut:

https://www.iusmentis.com/technology/hashfunctions/md5/

The MD5 function is a cryptographic algorithm that takes an input of arbitrary length and produces a message digest that is 128 bits long. The digest is sometimes also called the "hash" or "fingerprint" of the input. 

so since it is both a "crypto algo" and irreversible...it is the only correct answer.

This question is testing more than bullet point studying.
it is right Because it is asking for an irreversible value
this is BS, MD5 is a hashing algorithm for ensuring integrity cryptographic algorithms ensure confidentiality, the wordng of this question is wrong

questions.question_text: Which of the following cryptography algorithms will produce a fixed-length, irreversible output?
Which of the following is a resiliency strategy that allows a system to automatically adapt to workload changes?

discussion.content: Seems like a NET+ question...

choices.B: Create a trigger on the IPS and alert the security team when unsuccessful logins occur
choices.A: Implement rogue system detection and sensors
choices.C: Decrease the correlation threshold for alerts on the SIEM

discussion.content: Rogue System Detection provides near real-time discovery of rogue systems through the use of a Rogue System Sensor installed throughout your network. The sensor listens to network broadcast messages and DHCP responses to detect systems connected to the network.
It's more like a question from an English reading test instead of a technical test

The question clearly states that the SIEM was unable to alert of the presence of any of the penetration tester's devices. Implementing rogue system detection and sensors will alert the security team next time they encounter a similar situation. The answer is A.
the way i understand it is if the network detects a rogue system then right as the penetration tester connects to the network the security team will be notified
I believe it to be c. The threshold is to high so certian events are going un reported. Lower this and more events will be reported but run the risk of false positives.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester was able to connect to a company's internal network and perform scans and staged attacks for the duration of the testing period without being noticed. The SIEM did not alert the security team to the presence of the penetration tester's devices on the network. Which of the following would provide the security team with notification in a timely manner?
Which of the following involves the use of targeted and highly crafted custom attacks against a population of users who may have access to a particular service or program?

discussion.content:
Yes it is b
The biggest difference between spear phishing and phishing lies in the approach used by cyber criminals to carry out malicious activity.

Spear phishing is targeted and personalized to a specific individual, group, or organization. Conversely, regular phishing emails use a broad-strokes approach that involves sending bulk emails to massive lists of unsuspecting contacts. These phishing messages are often quickly crafted and don’t usually include personal information about the recipient.
key word is custom attacks which with spear phishing it's targeted towards a specific person

questions.question_text: When building a hosted datacenter, which of the following is the MOST important consideration for physical security within the datacenter?

discussion.content: This question actually made me mad, I cannot wait to be done with comptia after this.
Vote for C as well

comments.content: I would go with C too.

discussion.content: You need walls,doors before security guard. Answer is C for god's sake
I think it's security guards, secure enclosures is useless without Security guards.
other websites list the answer to this question as A- security guards

comments.content: I don’t understand why they answers to the questions are not the same. It’s really confusing
I interpret "within the datacenter" as the server room itself, so enclosures makes sense to me
Security guards tend to protect the perimeter of the datacenter
